drug.name: Pamidronic acid
drug.description: Pamidronic acid (INN) or pamidronate disodium (USAN), marketed as pamidronate disodium pentahydrate under the brand name Aredia, is a bisphosphonate.

article.citation: Zarychanski R, Elphee E, Walton P, Johnston J: Osteonecrosis of the jaw associated with pamidronate therapy. Am J Hematol. 2006 Jan;81(1):73-5.

drug.synthesis-reference: Edward C. Shinal, "Method for preparation of disodium pamidronate." U.S. Patent US6268524, issued February, 1988.
drug.indication: For the treatment of moderate or severe hypercalcemia associated with malignancy
drug.pharmacodynamics: Pamidronate is in a class of drugs called bisphosphonates. Pamidronate reduces breakdown of the bones. Pamidronate is used in the treatment of Paget's disease of bone; to reduce high levels of calcium in the blood associated with malignancy (cancer); and to reduce the breakdown of bone due to metastases of breast cancer or multiple myeloma.
drug.mechanism-of-action: The mechanism of action of pamidronate is inhibition of bone resorption. Pamidronate adsorbs to calcium phosphate (hydroxyapatite) crystals in bone and may directly block dissolution of this mineral component of bone. In vitro studies also suggest that inhibition of osteoclast activity contributes to inhibition of bone resorption. Pamidronate also targets farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP) synthase. Nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates (such as pamidronate, alendronate, risedronate, ibandronate and zoledronate) appear to act as analogues of isoprenoid diphosphate lipids, thereby inhibiting FPP synthase, an enzyme in the mevalonate pathway. Inhibition of this enzyme in osteoclasts prevents the biosynthesis of isoprenoid lipids (FPP and GGPP) that are essential for the post-translational farnesylation and geranylgeranylation of small GTPase signalling proteins. This activity inhibits osteoclast activity and reduces bone resorption and turnover. In postmenopausal women, it reduces the elevated rate of bone turnover, leading to, on average, a net gain in bone mass.
drug.toxicity: Side effects include an allergic reaction, kidney problems, seizures, low levels of calcium, magnesium, or phosphorus in the blood
drug.metabolism: Pamidronate is not metabolized and is exclusively eliminated by renal excretion
drug.absorption: Plasma concentration rises rapidly upon IV administration.
drug.half-life: The mean ± SD elimination half-life is 28 ± 7 hours
drug.route-of-elimination: Pamidronate is not metabolized and is exclusively eliminated by renal excretion.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as bisphosphonates. These are organic compounds containing two phosphonate groups linked together through a carbon atoms.

product.name: Aredia Liq Inj 3mg/ml
product.labeller: Geigy Pharmaceuticals, Ciba Geigy Canada Ltd.

manufacturers.manufacturer: Bedford laboratories div ben venue laboratories inc

Drugs for Treatment of Bone Diseases

polypeptide.name: Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase
polypeptide.specific-function: Key enzyme in isoprenoid biosynthesis which catalyzes the formation of farnesyl diphosphate (FPP), a precursor for several classes of essential metabolites including sterols, dolichols, carotenoids, and ubiquinones. FPP also serves as substrate for protein farnesylation and geranylgeranylation. Catalyzes the sequential condensation of isopentenyl pyrophosphate with the allylic pyrophosphates, dimethylallyl pyrophosphate, and then with the resultant geranylpyrophosphate to the ultimate product farnesyl pyrophosphate.
